content.text: Eduversal believes that every child has the right to a high-quality education in a mainstream setting. Inclusion is not just about placing students with diverse needs in a classroom; it is about creating a learning environment where every student feels valued, supported, and challenged to reach their full potential.

steps.title: Initial Concern
steps.desc: A classroom teacher, parent, or student raises a concern about academic progress, behavior, or wellbeing.

steps.title: Data Collection
steps.desc: The teacher gathers data (work samples, observation notes, assessment results) over 4-6 weeks.

steps.title: Referral
steps.desc: If concerns persist, the teacher completes a referral form for the Student Support Team (SST).

steps.title: SST Review
steps.desc: The SST (Learning Support Coordinator, Counselor, EAL Lead, Admin) reviews the case and recommends a course of action.

steps.title: Intervention/Assessment
steps.desc: Action may include targeted interventions, further observation, or a formal educational-psychological assessment.

content.text: We use a Multi-Tiered System of Supports (MTSS) to provide the appropriate level of support for every student.

rows: High-quality, differentiated instruction in the mainstream classroom.
Small-group interventions for students needing extra help in specific areas (e.g., reading group, math booster).
One-on-one support, specialized programs, or an Individual Education Plan (IEP) for students with significant needs.

subsections.title: English as an Additional Language (EAL) Support

content.text: EAL support is integrated into the curriculum to help students develop academic English proficiency.

content.title: Support Models
items: Sheltered Instruction: All subject teachers use EAL-friendly strategies (visuals, scaffolding, group work).
Push-In Support: An EAL specialist co-teaches in the mainstream classroom to support EAL learners.
Pull-Out Support: Students at beginning proficiency levels receive intensive, small-group English instruction for a portion of the day.

content.text: For students with diagnosed learning differences, an Individual Education Plan (IEP) is developed.

content.title: IEP Components
items: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound (SMART) goals.
Accommodations (e.g., extra time, preferential seating) and/or Modifications (e.g., altered curriculum).
Details of support services to be provided.

roles.title: Learning Support Coordinator
resp: Manages the SST, oversees IEPs, coordinates with external specialists.

roles.title: EAL Coordinator/Teacher
resp: Assesses EAL proficiency, provides direct instruction, supports subject teachers.

roles.title: School Counselor
resp: Provides social-emotional support, short-term counseling, and crisis intervention.

roles.title: Classroom Teacher
resp: Implements Tier 1 strategies and accommodations as per the IEP.

content.text: Parents are essential partners in supporting students with diverse needs.

items: Parents are involved in the referral and assessment process.
IEP meetings are held collaboratively with parents at least twice a year.
Regular communication between the support team and home is maintained to ensure consistency.
